questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is brought for a check-up. He can sit with support, babble monosyllables, and transfers objects from hand to hand. He responds to his name but doesn’t show stranger anxiety. Which of the following milestones is most delayed for this age?

A term newborn is brought for first visit at 3 days of age. The birth weight was 3.2 kg. The mother is concerned as the current weight is 2.9 kg. The baby is feeding well and passing urine 5–6 times/day. What is the appropriate next step?

A 5-year-old girl presents for height assessment. Her height is below the 3rd percentile while weight is between 10–25th percentile. Upper segment: lower segment ratio is increased. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Which of the following statements about growth patterns is true?

options.label: A
options.text: Head circumference increases by 2 cm in first 3 months of life

options.label: D
options.text: Head circumference equals chest circumference at 6 years

questions.correct_answer: A. Head circumference increases by 2 cm in first 3 months of life

questions.text: At what age does a typically developing child achieve the “pincer grasp”?
A fetus with suspected Potter syndrome is delivered at 35 weeks. What immediate neonatal complication is most likely?

options.label: C
options.text: Respiratory failure due to pulmonary hypoplasia

questions.correct_answer: C. Respiratory failure due to pulmonary hypoplasia
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Respiratory failure due to pulmonary hypoplasia

questions.text: A 9-month-old infant has not yet erupted any teeth. The rest of development is normal. What is the best next step?
A 4-year-old child has weight for height below the 3rd SD, with MUAC of 10.5 cm and visible wasting. Which category does this child fall under based on WHO classification?
At what age does a child’s birth weight triple and length increase by 50% of birth length?
Which of the following defines macrocephaly in a pediatric patient?
Which of the following is the correct sequence of pubertal events in females?
In males, which physical change is typically seen last during puberty?
A 15-year-old boy is evaluated for delayed puberty. He has tall stature, long limbs, gynecomastia, and small firm testes. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Which of the following is not a typical feature of Klinefelter syndrome?
A 4-month-old infant presents with premature closure of the sagittal suture. The head appears elongated anteroposteriorly with prominent forehead and occiput. What is this deformity called?
A newborn has a diamond-shaped soft area on the top of the head. It measures around 2.5 × 2.5 cm. What is the name and typical closure time of this fontanelle?
Which of the following cranial sutures lies between the frontal and parietal bones?
A 3-year-old child presents with intellectual disability, broad thumbs and big toes, beaked nose, and congenital heart disease. Which genetic condition is most likely?
A newborn has a high-pitched cat-like cry, microcephaly, hypertelorism, and severe intellectual disability. Which chromosomal abnormality is most likely?
Which of the following features is not typically seen in Cri-du-chat syndrome?
A 2-year-old girl who was developing normally begins losing purposeful hand use and speech, and develops hand-wringing stereotypies. Which gene mutation is most likely?
Which of the following correctly matches the milestone with its expected age?

An 11-month-old baby is placed on the floor. The image below shows the baby moving forward with the abdomen off the floor, weight supported on hands and knees. What developmental milestone is demonstrated by the child in this position?
Which of the following is the expected age for achieving the milestone shown in the image?
The behavior shown in the image is best described as which type of play?
A newborn, exclusively breastfed, presents on Day 3 with mild jaundice and adequate weight. He is passing meconium. What’s the best next step?
Which hormone is responsible for milk production, and for milk ejection?
Which immunoglobulin is most abundant in breast milk?
A mother of a preterm baby (32 weeks) is unable to breastfeed directly. Which is the best feeding option?
A newborn develops bleeding from the umbilical stump on Day 3. He is exclusively breastfed. What is the most likely deficiency?
A mother with hepatitis B wants to breastfeed her newborn. Baby received birth dose of HBV vaccine and HBIG. What advice should be given?
A newborn presents with poor weight gain and watery stools. History reveals that mother switches breasts every 1-2 minutes during feeding. Likely issue in the child can be:
A mother is HIV-positive and wants to breastfeed. She is on ART with good compliance. What should be advised?
questions.correct_answer: C. Exclusive breastfeeding with ART continuation
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Exclusive breastfeeding with ART continuation

questions.text: A 14-month-old child presents with weight-for-height below -3 SD, lethargy, and no appetite. MUAC is 11.2 cm. What is the next best step?

options.label: C
options.text: Give multivitamin syrup and send home

questions.correct_answer: A. Admit and initiate F-75 feeding
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Admit and initiate F-75 feeding

questions.text: Which of the following signs is a specific cutaneous marker of kwashiorkor?
A child has hypopigmented bands alternating with normal-colored hair. What is this sign called, and what does it indicate?
questions.correct_answer: A. Flag sign – Chronic protein deficiency
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Flag sign – Chronic protein deficiency

questions.text: Which of the following is not a WHO diagnostic criteria for SAM?
In the WHO SAM protocol, how long does the stabilization phase usually last?
A term baby fails to pass meconium within 48 hours. Abdomen is distended. X-ray shows dilated loops of bowel with air-fluid levels. What is the next best investigation?

A 5-day-old term neonate presents with persistent jaundice and dark yellow urine. On examination, hepatomegaly is noted. Total serum bilirubin is 11.8 mg/dL, of which direct bilirubin is 5.6 mg/dL. Liver enzymes are mildly elevated. The baby is gaining weight and is hemodynamically stable. Stool color is noted to be clay-colored. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
A baby born at 30 weeks develops respiratory distress shortly after birth. X-ray findings are shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Which of the following is not a component of APGAR score?
A 34-week neonate develops apnea, bradycardia, and desaturation. Which treatment is used prophylactically in such cases?
A term neonate presents with vomiting and a scaphoid abdomen. Breath sounds are decreased on left side. What is the likely diagnosis?
A three days old newborn baby came with complaints of breathing difficulty, and choking of feeds. The doctor on duty advised the x-ray. What is your best possible diagnosis?
A baby is born with heart rate <100 bpm, irregular respiration, and cyanosis. After drying and stimulation, what is the next immediate step in resuscitation?
A neonate presents with abdominal distension, bloody stools, and pneumatosis intestinalis on X-ray. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A term baby is born via vaginal delivery. At 1 minute, the heart rate is 90 bpm, baby shows some grimace to stimulation, irregular respiration, some flexion of limbs, and body is pink with blue extremities. What is the Apgar score at 1 minute?
A term newborn weighs 3.5 kg and measures 50 cm in length. What is the Ponderal Index (PI) of the newborn?
A girl presents for growth assessment. Her father is 174 cm tall and mother is 160 cm tall. What is the Mid-Parental Height (MPH) prediction for her?
A 10 kg child needs daily maintenance fluids. How much fluid is needed?

A healthy term baby is born with a head circumference of 35 cm. He is exclusively breastfed and developing normally with no signs of neurological abnormalities. At a routine 6-month follow-up visit, what is the expected head circumference of this infant?
A mother is concerned that her 3-month-old baby does not make eye contact or smile. At what age is the social smile typically expected?

A term baby is born to a mother with poorly controlled gestational diabetes. The baby weighs 4.2 kg and appears lethargic with poor feeding and jitteriness 2 hours after birth. What is the next best step in management?
A neonate is receiving effective positive pressure ventilation for the past 30 seconds. Heart rate is 55 bpm. What should be done next?
During neonatal resuscitation, what is the recommended ratio of chest compressions to ventilations?
According to NRP, how much time is given from birth to initiate ventilation if needed (i.e., the “Golden Minute”)?
Where is the heart rate best assessed during neonatal resuscitation?

options.label: C
options.text: Umbilical pulse or auscultation over precordium

questions.correct_answer: C. Umbilical pulse or auscultation over precordium
questions.explanation: Ans. C) Umbilical pulse or auscultation over precordium

questions.text: A term baby develops tonic posturing and twitching of the face 12 hours after birth. There is a history of prolonged labor and meconium-stained fluid. What is the most likely cause?
A newborn is noted to have rapid, rhythmic movements of all limbs while crying. The movements stop when the limbs are held firmly. What is the correct interpretation?
A term baby develops jaundice at 12 hours of life. The mother is O negative and the baby is A positive. What is the likely diagnosis?
A newborn has an asymmetrical Moro reflex. Right arm does not abduct fully during the reflex. What is the likely diagnosis?
What is the normal age of disappearance of the palmar grasp reflex?
A 3-year-old presents with night blindness and dry conjunctiva. What is the earliest ocular sign of Vitamin A deficiency?
A 2 year child with measles is admitted with eye signs of vitamin A deficiency. What is the correct dose of vitamin A (2nd dose) to be given for treatment?
A 1-year-old presents with bowed legs, frontal bossing, and widening of wrists. What is the most likely diagnosis?
Which is a classical neurological finding in Vitamin E deficiency?
What is the preferred route of Vitamin K prophylaxis in newborns?
A 5 year -old on polished rice develops hoarseness of voice, vomiting, and cardiomegaly. What is the likely cause?
A neonate presents with anencephaly on antenatal scan. What vitamin deficiency is responsible?
What is the daily recommended folic acid dose in pregnancy for NTD prevention?
A malnourished 2-year-old presents with swollen gums, joint pain, and bleeding. X-ray shows ground glass appearance. What is the likely diagnosis?
A 10-month-old exclusively breastfed baby develops pallor and irritability. CBC shows macrocytic anemia. What is the likely deficiency?
A neonate on isoniazid therapy develops seizures unresponsive to phenobarbital. What is the likely cause?
What is the classic tongue appearance in riboflavin deficiency?
